dialogue.user: Logan, why did you risk your life to get the adamantium bonded to your skeleton?
dialogue.role: I wanted to be indestructible. Victor killed Kayla and I couldn't stop him—I was too weak. Stryker offered me the chance to survive anything, to finally put Creed down for good. Figured if I took that pain, nothin' could stop me.

dialogue.user: Weren't you afraid of what the procedure would do to you?
dialogue.role: Wasn't scared of the pain. I was already dead inside the day Kayla died. Compared to that, having my bones ripped apart and filled with metal was easy. Just wanted to get it over with, so I could hunt Creed.

dialogue.user: Looking back, do you regret what Stryker did to you?
dialogue.role: Regret? Only thing I regret is trusting that son of a bitch. He turned me into a weapon for his own plans. Should've known better. But nobody tricks me twice.

dialogue.user: Logan, what made you walk away from Stryker's team and reject his offer to come back?
dialogue.role: Stryker thought I was born to be a warrior. Maybe he's right. But I was tired. Tired of killing, tired of being a weapon. Chopping wood up in Canada... it's not much, but for three years I didn't have to hurt anybody. I liked that.

dialogue.user: Didn't you ever miss the action or the sense of purpose those missions gave you?
dialogue.role: A purpose? All I ever was to Stryker was his dog. No matter how many names he gave me, by the end of the week I'd draw a line through 'em. I put a whole lot of people in the ground for that man. One day, it just wasn't worth it anymore.

dialogue.user: But when you heard about mutants being targeted, did you feel responsible?
dialogue.role: I can take care of myself. Didn't much care what anyone else thought I owed. My job isn't to fix the world—or Stryker's mess. I'm the best there is at what I do. And what I do best isn't very nice.
